values: GHGs are prescribed from annual timeseries. Aerosol concentrations are prescribed from 3D distributions of monthly timeseries with long-term annual trends.
Y: Prescribed concentrations, distributions or time series data
CO2 concentrations follow the RCP scenarios (Meinshausen et al., 2011; doi:10.1007/s10584-011-0156-z), and are interpolated from one year to the next.
Y: Prescribed concentrations, distributions or time series data
CH4 concentrations follow the RCP scenarios (Meinshausen et al., 2011; doi:10.1007/s10584-011-0156-z), and are interpolated from one year to the next.
Y: Prescribed concentrations, distributions or time series data
N2O concentrations follow the RCP scenarios (Meinshausen et al., 2011; doi:10.1007/s10584-011-0156-z), and are interpolated from one year to the next.
Y: Prescribed concentrations, distributions or time series data
Spatial distributions of vertically resolved (stratospheric and tropospheric) and monthly resolved ozone are prescribed following Cionni et al. (2011; https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-11-11267-2011).
Y: Prescribed concentrations, distributions or time series data
Spatial distributions of vertically resolved (stratospheric and tropospheric) and monthly resolved ozone are prescribed following Cionni et al. (2011; https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-11-11267-2011).
Y: Prescribed concentrations, distributions or time series data
Option 2: CFC-12 is provided as actual concentrations and any other gases are provided as an equivalence concentration of CFC-11
CFC-11 & CFC-12 concentrations follow the RCP scenarios, and are interpolated from one year to the next.
Y: Prescribed concentrations, distributions or time series data
Sulfate aerosol is part of the aerosol forcing: see 1.12.6 & 1.12.7

Type B: Explosive volcanic aerosol returns rapidly to constant (average volcano)
Type E: Explosive volcanic aerosol set to constant (average volcano) background

Semi-Lagrangian two-time level hydrostatic dynamical core with a vertical terrain-following hybrid sigma pressure coordinate on a centered finite-differencing spherical regular grid.
Other: Davies et al (1976) exponential relaxation in boundary zone
The radiative transfer scheme was taken from the ECMWF model. Solar has no specific name; terrestrial known as RRTM.

The radiation transfer code is taken from IFS-ECMWF CY31r1. Documentation: IFS Documentation CY31R1 - Part IV: Physical Processes, Chapter 2, https://www.ecmwf.int/en/elibrary/9221-ifs-documentation-cy31r1-part-iv-physical-processes
Short wave radiation scheme taken from IFS-ECMWF CY31r1. Originally developed by Fouqart and Bonnel (1980). No common name.
ice water path: Integrated ice water path through the cloud kg m-2
liquid water path: Integrated liquid water path through the cloud kg m-2
Rapid Radiation Transfer Model (RRTM); implementation taken from IFS-ECMWF CY31r1
ice water path: Integrated ice water path through the cloud kg m-2
liquid water path: Integrated liquid water path through the cloud kg m-2
EDMF scheme for boundary-layer turbulence in the mixed layer; Tiedtke scheme for shallow/deep/mid-level convection.

Boundary-layer turbulence  is represented by the Eddy-Diffusivity Mass-Flux (EDMF) scheme.  The boundary-layer scheme in RACMO is taken from IFS-ECMWF CY31r1. The original first-order K-diffusion scheme is replaced by a formulation based on a moist TKE variable (see Lenderink and Holtslag, 2004). For the stable boundary layer see Baas et al. (2008). Shallow, mid-level and penetrative cumulus convection by the so-called Tiedtke Mass-Flux scheme (see Tiedtke,1989; Nordeng, 1994). The cumulus convection scheme in RACMO is taken from IFS-ECMWF CY31r1. Documentation: IFS Documentation CY31R1 - Part IV: Physical Processes, Chapter 3 & 5, https://www.ecmwf.int/en/elibrary/9221-ifs-documentation-cy31r1-part-iv-physical-processes
Other: moist prognostic TKE without horizontal advection
CAPE: Mass flux determined by CAPE, convectively available potential energy.
bulk: A bulk mass flux scheme is used
separate diagnosis: Deep and Shallow convection schemes use different thermodynamic closure criteria

Stratiform clouds are described by a prognostic cloud scheme (Tiedtke, 1993; Tompkins, 2002,2007) and a single-moment cloud microphysics scheme. Documentation: IFS Documentation CY31R1 - Part IV: Physical Processes, Chapter 6, https://www.ecmwf.int/en/elibrary/9221-ifs-documentation-cy31r1-part-iv-physical-processes

Prognostic cloud scheme for cloud water/cloud ice and cloud fraction is taken from IFS-ECMWF CY31r1. Originally developed by Tiedtke (1993), major extensions added by Tompkins (2002,2009). Implementation in RACMO close to the original scheme. Documentation: IFS Documentation CY31R1 - Part IV: Physical Processes, Chapter 6, https://www.ecmwf.int/en/elibrary/9221-ifs-documentation-cy31r1-part-iv-physical-processes
Unified treatment of convective, stratiform and boundary-layer  clouds.
Other: stratiform diabatic heating and colling
Other: sum of liquid and ice is advected
Other: sum of liquid and ice is advected
maximum-random: combination of maximum and random overlap between clouds

Subgrid-scale orographic drag, developed by Lott and Miller (1997), taken from IFS-ECMWF CY31r1. It determines tendencires to the horizontal wind components from gravity-wave drag for levels above, and from blocked-flow drag for levels below an effective blocking height. Documentation: IFS Documentation CY31R1 - Part IV: Physical Processes, Chapter 4,  https://www.ecmwf.int/en/elibrary/9221-ifs-documentation-cy31r1-part-iv-physical-processes
SW radiation: Shortwave solar spectral irradiance.
Time independent forcing though the aerosol climatology's stratospheric component
Davies (1976) type relaxation according to tanh-function: 8 points for mass fields and 16 points for momentum fields
hybrid sigma-pressure: sigma system near terrain and isobaric above

RACMO22E is the 2012 release of the regional climate model RACMO2. The model dynamics is taken from the numerical weather prediction model HIRLAM, version 6.3.7.  The framework of physical parameterizations is taken from IFS-ECMWF CY31r1 but a number of modifications has been applied. The model has a hydrostatic dynamical core and a hybrid-sigma vertical pressure coordinate. The spatial discretization uses a rotated latitude longitude grid mapping and, in standard configuration, 40 levels in the vertical. RACMO22E employs a tiled land surface scheme. Documentatiovan Meijgaard, E., L.H. van Ulft, W.J. van de Berg, F.C. Bosveld, B.J.J.M. van den Hurk, G. Lenderink, A.P. Siebesma (2008). The KNMI regional atmospheric climate model RACMO, version 2.1 ( https://www.knmi.nl/kennis-en-datacentrum/publicatie/the-knmi-regional-atmospheric-climate-model-racmo-version-2-1 ) ; van Meijgaard, E., L.H. van Ulft, G. Lenderink, S.R. de Roode, E. L. Wipfler, R. Boers, R.M.A. Timmermans (2012). Refinement and application of a regional atmospheric model for climate scenario calculations of Western Europe. KVR Research Rep. 054/12, 44 pp ( https://library.wur.nl/WebQuery/wurpubs/fulltext/312258 ; http://climexp.knmi.nl/publications/FinalReport_KvR-CS06.pdf ).

n:
Other: sixth-order low-pass imlicit tangent filter developed by Raymond (MWR 116) applied to high resolution orography
RACMO2.1 was based on ECMWF physics package IFS cy23r4. RACMO22E is based in IFS cy31r1.

van Meijgaard, E., L.H. van Ulft, G. Lenderink, S.R. de Roode, L. Wipfler, R. Boers, R.M.A. Timmermans (2012). Refinement and application of a regional atmospheric model  for climate scenario calculations of Western Europe. Final report in Climate changes Spatial planning program. KvR report number KvR 054/12. ISBN/EAN 978-90-8815-046-3. 
 https://library.wur.nl/WebQuery/wurpubs/fulltext/312258 ;  http://climexp.knmi.nl/publications/FinalReport_KvR-CS06.pdf

RACMO is the Regional Atmospheric Climate MOdel developed at KNMI. It is based on the hydrostatic dynamical kernel of the HIRLAM numerical weather prediction model and the physics package of ECMWF IFS cycle 31r1. The model employs a hybrid vertical coordinate and a tile-based land surface scheme with physiography based on ECOCLIMAP.
surface pressure (ps), temperature (ta), specific humidity (hus), zonal (ua) and meridional (va) wind components
surface pressure (ps), temperature (ta), specific humidity (hus), zonal (ua) and meridional (va) wind components
Sea surface temperature (tos) from the driving reanalysis ERA-Interim.
Sea-ice concentration (sic)  from the driving reanalysis ERA-Interim
At frequency supplied by driving GCM: 6-hourly or daily
At frequency supplied by driving GCM: 6-hourly, daily or monthly

Parameterized aerosol effect (optical depth, absorption and scattering; wave length dependent) on radiative fluxes (only direct effect). Six aerosol classes (land, maritime, desert, urban, volcanic active, stratospheric background). Aerosol concentrations (spatial distributions, vertical profiles, monthly variations) are imported for the following species: sulfate (so4), secondary organic aerosol (soa), organic matter (hydrophobic/-phylic), black carbon (hydrophobic/-phylic), desert dust (4 size classes), and sea salt (4 size classes), and subsequently mapped on the aerosol classes. Aerosol input datasets for historical period (until 2005) are based on Lamarque et al. (2010; doi:10.5194/acp10-7017-2010); for projections (from 2006 onwards) on Van Vuuren et al. (2011; doi:10.1007/s10584-011-0148-z) and Lamarque et al. (2013 ; doi:10.1007/s10584-011-0155-0). In the evaluation experiment, historical is taken for the years until 2005, and RCP8.5 for the years after 2005.

Prescribed aerosol forcing is adopted from EC-Earth2.3 (version used for CMIP5 simulations). References: Hazeleger et al. (2012; doi:10.1007/s00382-011-1228-5) and Van Noije et al. (2014; doi:10.5194/gmd-7-2435-2014).

Parameterized aerosol effect (optical depth, absorption and scattering; wave length dependent) on radiative fluxes (only direct effect). Six aerosol classes (land, maritime, desert, urban, volcanic active, stratospheric background). Aerosol concentrations (spatial distributions, vertical profiles, monthly variations) are imported for the following species: sulfate (so4), secondary organic aerosol (soa), organic matter (hydrophobic/-phylic), black carbon (hydrophobic/-phylic), desert dust (4 size classes), and sea salt (4 size classes), and subsequently mapped on the aerosol classes. Aerosols input datasets for historical period (until 2005) are based on Lamarque et al. (2010; doi:10.5194/acp10-7017-2010); for projections (from 2006 onwards) on Van Vuuren et al. (2011; doi:10.1007/s10584-011-0148-z) and Lamarque et al. (2013 ; doi:10.1007/s10584-011-0155-0).

Prescribed aerosol forcing is adopted from EC-Earth2.3 (version used for CMIP5 simulations). References: Hazeleger et al. (2012; doi:10.1007/s00382-011-1228-5) and Van Noije et al. (2014; doi:10.5194/gmd-7-2435-2014).
Spatial distributions of vertically resolved (stratospheric and tropospheric) ozone are prescribed following Cionni et al. (2011; https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-11-11267-2011).
Prescribed ozone forcing is adopted from EC-Earth2.3 (version used for CMIP5 simulations)
Spatial distributions of vertically resolved (stratospheric and tropospheric) ozone are prescribed following Cionni et al. (2011; https://doi.org/10.5194/acp-11-11267-2011).
Prescribed ozone forcing is adopted from EC-Earth2.3 (version used for CMIP5 simulations)
Leaf Area Index (LAI): climatology (10-day frequency; no interannual variations). Other land cover parameters: static
Leaf Area Index (LAI): climatology (10-day frequency; no interannual variations). Other land cover parameters: static

ECOCLIMAP classes are mapped on HTESSEL land surface model bare ground, and low and high vegetation types and coverages. Leaf Area Index (LAI) climatology is inferred from MODIS on a 10-day frequency.
